StudyInfo.StudyNameEntrez: Metagenomic study of the human skin microbiome associated with acne

Policy.acknowledgement_statement: Funding support for the Metagenomic Study of the Human Skin Microbiome Associated with Acne (acne microbiome project) was provided through the NIH Human Microbiome Project (HMP), grant 1UH2AR057503. The Acne microbiome project is one of the demonstration projects funded as part of the HMP. The datasets used for the analyses described in this manuscript were obtained from dbGAP at https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/gap through dbGAP accession number phs000263. Data for the acne microbiome project were provided by Huiying Li, Ph.D. on behalf of all the collaborators. For publications using these data please cite botht he dbGaP accession number and and the original publication: Fitz-Gibbon, S., Tomida, S., Chiu, B.H., Nguyen, L., Du, C., Liu, M.H., Elashoff, D., Erfe, M.C., Loncaric, A., Kim, J., et al. (2013). Propionibacterium acnes Strain Populations in the Human Skin Microbiome Associated with Acne. Journal of Investigative Dermatology 133, 2152-2160. (https://doi.org/10.1038/jid.2013.21).

GSR_Access.gsr_mode_label: Unrestricted access (institution did not respond within six months)

ConsentGroup.title: Human Microbiome Research
ConsentGroup.name: HMP
ConsentGroup.Use-Restriction: These data may be be used only for studies related to the human microbiome. Sequence data generated from microbiome samples will be used only for the purpose of studying the microbial components of the microbiome and will not be used to make inferences about the human host DNA itself.

StudyInfo.StudyNameEntrez: Metagenomic study of the human skin microbiome associated with acne
StudyInfo.Description: Acne vulgaris affects 17 million Americans, more than 80% of the people of age 12-24. The goal of this study is to investigate the relationship between acne pathogenesis and the skin microbiota residing in the microcomedones. This study will enroll approximately 100 healthy individuals and acne patients, both male and female with age 13 or older. Data obtained from this study will help better understand the disease pathogenesis and may lead to the development of new effective therapeutic strategies for treatment of acne.
StudyInfo.StudyHistory: This study is part of the NIH Human Microbiome Demonstration Project, started in May 2009.

Policy.acknowledgement_statement: INSTRUCTIONS: This study has not provided a suggested acknowledgement statement. However, Approved Users are expected to acknowledge the Submitting Investigator(s) who submitted data from the original study to an NIH-designated data repository, the primary funding organization that supported the Submitting Investigator(s), and the NIH-designated data repository (e.g., dbGaP). The acknowledgment statement should include the dbGaP accession number to the specific version of the dataset(s) analyzed.
